etymologies: Middle English (originally denoting a utensil for pouring liquids): from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German schōpe ‘waterwheel bucket’; from a West Germanic base meaning ‘draw water’; related to the verb shape

definitions: a utensil resembling a spoon, with a long handle and a deep bowl, used for removing powdered, granulated, or semisolid substances (such as ice cream) from a container

examples.text: the powder is packed in tubs in which a measuring scoop is provided

shortDefinitions: utensil resembling spoon, with short handle and deep bowl

definitions: a short-handled deep shovel used for moving grain, coal, etc.
shortDefinitions: short-handled deep shovel used for moving grain

definitions: a moving bowl-shaped part of a digging machine, dredger, or other mechanism into which material is gathered.
shortDefinitions: moving bowl-shaped part of digging machine, dredger, or other mechanism

definitions: a long-handled surgical instrument that resembles a spoon.
a quantity taken up by a scoop

examples.text: an apple pie with scoops of ice cream on top

definitions: a piece of news published by a newspaper or broadcast by a television or radio station in advance of its rivals

examples.text: reporters at the city's three tabloid papers usually compete for scoops

shortDefinitions: piece of news published by newspaper or broadcast by television or radio station in advance of its rivals

definitions: pick up and move (something) with a scoop

examples.text: Philip began to scoop grain into his bag

shortDefinitions: pick up and move something with scoop

definitions: create (a hollow or hole) with or as if with a scoop

examples.text: a hole was scooped out in the floor of the dwelling

shortDefinitions: create hollow or hole with or as if with scoop

definitions: pick up (someone or something) in a swift, fluid movement

examples.text: he laughed and scooped her up in his arms

shortDefinitions: pick up person or thing in swift

definitions: publish a news story before (a rival reporter, newspaper, or radio or television station)

examples.text: time and again we have scooped our rivals with the top stories and pictures
